# Problem

https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/21472 removed `:hardcopy` in favor of `:TOhtml`, but `:TOhtml` requires extra steps.
 
# Proposal

Add a `:Hardcopy` command that does the following:

1. generates HTML
    - https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/27097
3. saves the file to reasonable place (~/Downloads or `stdpath('run')` ?)
    - `:TOhtml` won't save the file if it can't write to the directory, example:
      ```
      :help syntax
      :TOhtml
      ```
4. dispose the junk buffer/window created by `:TOhtml`
5. open the HTML file in the system web browser
    - use netrw `netrw#BrowseX()` for this (FUTURE: add `vim.open()`)
    - if web browser not found, fallback to `troff` ?

Then you just hit ctrl-p to print.

_Originally posted by @justinmk in https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/21472#issuecomment-1369645909_

comment_data.body: Since `:TOhtml` needs to be rewritten anyway to support extmarks, maybe those can be combined (e.g., `:TOhtml print`)?
Which behavior is expected if the system doesn't have any browser?
I can take care of that!

> Since `:TOhtml` needs to be rewritten anyway to support extmarks, maybe those can be combined (e.g., `:TOhtml print`)?

- `:TOhtml` itself is not a great interface, don't want to plant more roots there. I could imagine a future generalized interface (`:export` ?).
- Some sort of main entrypoint like `:Hardcopy` leaves the door open for a "provider" model I guess, too.

> Which behavior is expected if the system doesn't have any browser?

Unspecified for now.

> Which behavior is expected if the system doesn't have any browser?

What about using `troff` as a fallback to handle these cases? It's a simple yet popular typesetting system included in many Linux distros!

The only issue I see is with portability since its installation on Windows is a bit messy (you have to do that trough GNUWin32) but having a fallback to handle the absence of browser is a non-issue in Windows and MacOS since the browser is part of the OS and not an external application.

My main point is that `:TOhtml` needs a rewrite so it would pay off to consider this in tandem -- whichever is the last function standing. A generic `:Export` sounds good to me, too (could hook into `pandoc`, too, for PDF export on Linux).

In any case, it should be a plugin (like `:Man`) and have sensible platform-specific defaults (for the Main Three).

> A generic `:Export` sounds good to me, too (could hook into `pandoc`, too, for PDF export on Linux).

Which file format would you use as the output of this new `:Export` for later conversion by pandoc?
HTML, probably.

Hi, I came up with a [first prototype of the plugin](https://github.com/CarbonHeartDev/neovim/blob/37528ed7a6ebbb28dc9cb803a38fd598f526926f/runtime/plugin/hardcopy.vim), I know it lacks license header and docs but at the moment it's just a POC to see if I'm headed to the correct direction. Other things on which I have to work on the next days are sensible file path defaults for the Main Three, as said by @clason, (at the moment I save the html export in a temporary file) and the `troff` fallback which I proposed.

Excuse me if it took a while to come up with this first version but I'm still a newbie to Lua, VimScript and the Neovim codebase.

> came up with a [first prototype of the plugin](https://github.com/CarbonHeartDev/neovim/blob/37528ed7a6ebbb28dc9cb803a38fd598f526926f/runtime/plugin/hardcopy.vim), I know it lacks license header and docs but at the moment it's just a POC to see if I'm headed to the correct direction.

looks like the right direction, though we'd want it to be in Lua.

What are use cases for `TOhtml` ?

There thousands of JS utils (including simple editors) that can highlight source code in much more simpler fashion.

The only use case is to output a buffer as nvim would render it with `syntax on`.

I agree, there are much better tools for the job. A TS-based solution would be ideal here.

> A TS-based solution would be ideal here.

sure, but to avoid confusing @CarbonHeartDev  (or anyone else who picks this up), the near-term goal of providing a :hardcopy replacement can use :TOhtml because that's what we currently have. Later, :TOhtml can be replaced by a TS solution.
I saw which user @pynappo made some interesting contribution to my plugin, if he's okay with that we can collaborate on this.
@CarbonHeartDev Can I also collaborate?

Sure @Nicola-Bini!

At the moment the browser based printing system is complete (you can test it by [downloading the plugin from my fork](https://github.com/CarbonHeartDev/neovim/blob/ExportBufferCommand/runtime/plugin/hardcopy.lua), putting it in a directory included in your Neovim runtime path, opening Neovim and launching the command `:Hardcopy`) but any idea to make it better it is welcome.

Currently I'm working on fallback systems for headless machines which cannot open files on a browser. The *nix version of this will be based on `lpstat`, `lpr` and some CLI based text formatting tool (I'm undecided between `groff` and simpler alternatives such as `nl` and `pr`). To date I implemented a function to query the system and get a list of available printers. Now I need to display that list in a floating window allowing the user to pick a printer of his choice and to set basic printing options (number of copies, front-back, line numbering enabled/disabled...) before launching the print job (which in concrete will translate to calling `vim.fm.system()` sending the selected buffer content on a CLI pipeline composed by one or more formatting commands and `lpr` in the end). Once the fallback printing is done for *nix OSs I want to do something similar for Windows systems too but since Windows is a little less "CLI-friendly" I have to investigate if I can obtain good enough results.

In the last days I was pretty busy with my job and my studies and I wasn't able to make meaningful progress so for me any contribution is more welcome now than ever.

Hi @CarbonHeartDev,

Thank you for the summary. 

I can work on the floating window, do you have a clear list of printing options in mind? If not, I can come up with something using the MacOS printing settings as a reference. Perhaps I could start with [these arguments](https://man7.org/linux/man-pages/man1/lpr.1.html).

![Screenshot 2023-01-26 at 8 38 51 PM](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/63654846/214991839-4ebfa188-3196-4f1d-a5a7-8adc45af85e7.png)


On another note, I do not have experience with neovim apis and the tools you have mentioned, please do not hesitate to point out any incorrectness

@Nicola-Bini I think which selecting the printer, the number of copies, toggling the line numbering and eventually orientation would be enough, maybe tonight or tomorrow I can write a printing function with said parameters in order to allow you to focus on the GUI while I take care of interfacing with printing and formatting tools.

Paper size selection and double sided print toggle would be nice to have but after hours of research I wasn't able to query CUPS to find which types of paper are supported by a certain printer of if double sided is supported in order to show these on the interface only when actually supported by the selected printer so eventually it's going to be user's responsibility to selecting options which works for his printer and I'm not sure which that's a good UX but I'm open to feedback on this regard and on anything else.

Hi @CarbonHeartDev,

I made a first draft of the window. I would like some feedback from you. do you have some time to meet on discord/zoom to go over it?

We need an API to get the precalculated appearance of each character in the buffer, at least background and foreground colors. 
With that in place we can join contiguous characters with the same "appearance". Starting from that implementing backends for rendering several formats (html, rtf,groff) will be relatively easy  as  we can borrow the "know-how" from pygments. We could even render to PDF for printing in pure lua  by using <https://github.com/catseye/pdf.lua>

I was trying to accomplish that, but having to use `vim.inspect_pos()` to get the highlight groups and then apply them according to the priorities seems slow and error-prone.

It should be noted that least with the existing `:TOhtml` line numbers & line wrapping do not work together - the wrapped lines start where the number starts. This should likely be somehow addressed for a `:hardcopy` replacement based on `:TOhtml`.

The `:Hardcopy` is removed in the latest dev release. I don't think it's worth pursuing this feature.

https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/040f1459849ab05b04f6bb1e77b3def16b4c2f2b/runtime/doc/news.txt

> The `:Hardcopy` is removed in the latest dev release. I don't think it's worth pursuing this feature.
> 
> [`040f145`/runtime/doc/news.txt](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/040f1459849ab05b04f6bb1e77b3def16b4c2f2b/runtime/doc/news.txt)

I think it's been removed for a while, and that's why this issue exists? The original comment in this thread has the pull request where it was removed, namely #21472.

I +1 this as an (apparently rare?) user of hardcopy. It was removed without replacement.
I frequently print a bunch of files with :bufdo execute 'hardcopy' and would rather not have to open each HTML in a browser and print it.

In my view any alternative that requires manually clicking anything after :hardcopy is not the same.

I can see how a :TOhtml replacement could work by saving the output to a temp file, running a different command for the html -> pdf step, then calling lpr on it.

But I would rather that existed before hardcopy is scrapped.
@tjakway There are standalone tools like [highlight](https://gitlab.com/saalen/highlight) that can be used instead via commandline or inside neovim cmd e.g. `!highlight ... %`

@tjakway As I'm still trying to search for an alternative that works without breaking with line numbers that I can use as soon as possible, I've also been looking into HTML  PDF conversion tools, and the two that seem to work best are Chromium and its derivates via `--headless --print-to-pdf` (though as far as I can tell you cannot change a lot of options there; also Firefox doesn't seem to have a similar option sadly and if this was going to be the way such a feature would be implemented it would require people to install a Chromium-based browser *solely* for printing) or `weasyprint` (which i should note however is not exactly *fast*, it's okay but calling it for a bunch of files will take a few seconds), since everything else I have tried either doesn't deal with line wrapping at all or has issues with colours.

As a possible solution, until a better one is found, I think the best thing to do is either 1. downgrade the neovim version to one before 0.9.0 for the foreseeable future, 2. switch to `vim` or 3. (the solution I'm probably going to go with) install `vim` alongside `neovim` and call into it for `:hardcopy` purposes.

Well the new Manjaro update to nvim 0.9 just broke my beloved nvim hardcopy can we keep the hardcopy and related print commands in nvim please?  I don't see the appeal in moving to web browser html printing when I could more quickly print with hardcopy and preview with a 'open in pdf' command with no browser open at all. I honestly use and like it so much that I will be rolling back to 0.8 nvim or going back to vim where these commands still exist.

My setup was as simple as two mappings and two common repo packages `ps2pdf` and `zathura`. 
```
map <C-p> :hardcopy!<CR>
map <S-p> :hardcopy! > %.ps <Bar> !ps2pdf %.ps && rm %.ps && zathura %.pdf &<CR><CR>
```

```

  - Options removed:
    - `printdevice`
    - `printencoding`
    - `printexpr`
    - `printfont`
    - `printheader`
    - `printmbcharset`
```

right there was also the printoptions that took time to set up how I like it:
```
" PRINT OPTIONS via :hardcopy
set printoptions=paper:A4    "paper size 
set printoptions=formfeed:n  "treat form feed characters (0x0c) as a normal print character 
set printfont=:h15           "font size

"set printoptions=left:0pc    ""goes with portrait line

"set printoptions=bottom:0pc  ""
```

So if I understand correctly this workflow was broken without a replacement? I used hardcopy to print my resumes. Printing to HTML doesn't work because it includes a lot of formatting that I didn't need - and line numbers and such. Now I have to go through and fix it manually? That sounds like a lot of work, why was this removed again?

EDIT: not to mention the header and footer. I don't know HTML so I don't really know how to fix that kind of thing. Can anyone recommend a plugin or anything that could solve this problem?

It's not like I *only* need this feature. There are many reasons I don't use Vim.

unfortunate. at least the 5 hour config migration back to Vim today is ~~mostly~~ where I need it. was always going to be a gamble building good config on a fork. 

:hardcopy Vim is way too convinent to pass up for me.

edit: to any onlookers I just wanted to mention I have decided to also give nvim's new file printing angle a try as well, like it doesn't hurt to maintain a config for each tbh I will see how I like it even though I love to use hardcopy. Instant print magic.

If the direction of neovim is to scrap features people are clearly using, and then saying "just go back to vim if you don't like it", this project is taking a different turn to what drew me to use neovim...

If you:
- Fix hardcopy for windows
- Make hardcopy work for Treesitter and extmarks
- Make hardcopy easy to maintain

Then we can add it back.

> If the direction of neovim is to scrap features people are clearly using, and then saying "just go back to vim if you don't like it", this project is taking a different turn to what drew me to use neovim...

Given the popularity of the project, **every** feature is bound to have at least 1 user, that's not going to stop us removing features if we don't deem them valuable enough. See https://neovim.io/doc/user/vim_diff.html#nvim-removed for the full list of features we have removed since forking Vim.
https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/27097 adds treesitter (and more) support to `:TOhtml`, which opens the door for  `:Hardcopy`.
